title: 108_hr3722
content: The Act may be cited as the "Undocumented Alien Emergency Medical Assistance Amendments of 2004". Congress finds that medical care for undocumented aliens should only be provided to protect the health and safety of US citizens, save lives in emergencies, and stabilize conditions for repatriation. Reimbursement for emergency hospital services should require information for prompt removal of aliens. Employers must complete employment verification procedures for undocumented aliens. Employers completing employment verification procedures should be responsible for unpaid emergency services provided to undocumented aliens. SEC. 3. CONDITIONS FOR RECEIPT OF FEDERAL ASSISTANCE FOR EMERGENCY SERVICES FOR UNDOCUMENTED ALIENS. The Medicare Prescription Drug, Improvement, and Modernization Act of 2003 is amended to include requirements for eligible providers, specifically hospitals, regarding payment for eligible services for undocumented aliens. This includes costs for emergency medical transportation and evacuation. The Medicare Prescription Drug, Improvement, and Modernization Act of 2003 now includes requirements for hospitals to collect immigration-related information for undocumented aliens before receiving payment for eligible services, including emergency medical transportation and evacuation to a foreign country for healthcare services. The Medicare Prescription Drug, Improvement, and Modernization Act of 2003 mandates hospitals to collect immigration-related information from aliens before receiving payment for services, including personal and financial data, citizenship, immigration status, address in the US, health insurance information, and details of current employer. The hospital is required to collect immigration-related information from aliens, including personal and financial data, citizenship, immigration status, address in the US, health insurance information, and details of current employer. The hospital must obtain identifiers for the alien and record them in a specified digital format for verification purposes. The hospital must collect and transmit alien identity and immigration status information to the Secretary of Homeland Security in a specified digital format. Hospital records must be maintained for at least 5 years and made available for examination. The Secretary of Homeland Security will provide technical support to hospitals under this section. The hospital receives software, training, and technical support services at no cost to comply with requirements. The Secretary of Homeland Security takes prompt action to review information, determine removability of aliens, and initiate removal proceedings. Undocumented aliens who obtain... An undocumented alien receiving services from a hospital without payment or providing accurate information may be considered removable under immigration law. Employers of such aliens making payments for services may also have responsibilities under the law. Employers may be liable to the Secretary for payments made to undocumented alien workers who meet specific criteria, as defined in subsection (c)(5)(A) of the Immigration and Nationality Act. Conditions for exemption under subparagraph (A)(iii) require full compliance with employment verification system requirements outlined in section 274A(b) of the Immigration and Nationality Act. The employer must enroll the alien in a State workmen's compensation plan and provide health benefits with emergency medical and hospitalization coverage as specified by the Secretary. The employer also assumes responsibility for any cost-sharing. The employer must enroll the alien in a State workmen's compensation plan and provide health benefits with emergency medical and hospitalization coverage as specified by the Secretary, including deductibles and coinsurance. The employer must verify the alien's employment authorization through the basic employment verification pilot program or other means provided by the Secretary of Homeland Security. The liability of an employer and alien is limited. The liability of an employer under this subsection is limited to employing an undocumented alien worker at the time eligible services are provided. Hospitals are not required to provide care to undocumented aliens if they can be transported to their country without significant medical deterioration. The text discusses the likelihood of medical deterioration for aliens in need of extraordinary medical treatment exceeding $50,000, with regulations effective as of the Medicare Prescription Drug, Improvement, and Modernization Act of 2003. The Drug, Improvement, and Modernization Act of 2003 requires the Secretary of Homeland Security, in consultation with the Secretary of Health and Human Services, to issue interim regulations within 60 days and final regulations within one year. Additionally, an annual report on implementation is mandated. The Secretary of Homeland Security, in consultation with the Secretary of Health and Human Services, must submit an annual report on the implementation of section 1011 of the Medicare Prescription Drug, Improvement, and Modernization Act of 2003. The report should include a cost analysis of Federal expenditures, a description of assistance provided to hospitals, and the number of undocumented aliens removed. The Secretary of State will analyze the feasibility of negotiating treaties with foreign states to provide payment for international medical evacuation for their nationals needing emergency healthcare in the US. The Secretary of State will submit a report to committees on the feasibility of imposing a surcharge on nationals of foreign states to cover medical costs and international medical evacuation, in cases where treaties for payment are not in effect.
